Clumsy, flawed, but still very fun!
I wish it was a lot better than it was.
I've seen this film three times and it's a joy every time.
I don't think Peter Berg is a very good director.
"As much as I want to, I can't live in your book anymore." Christ.
Feels much longer the second time around.
Brad Pitt runs from zombies for two hours, and looks back every time to ponder stuff while keeping a steady pace with everyone running around him.

A very Spike Lee bank robbery. What is up with that one weird shot of Denzel that takes you out of the entire film?edit: just got on twitter for the first time in several months to see that this earnest, innocuous comment i wrote as a 21 year old who had never seen a spike lee and used (still uses) this website as a personal journal to log thoughts on movies made some grown men on twitter VERY mad.‚Ä¶
It's the less violent version of Olympus Has Fallen. It's just as stupid as that movie is, but in other ways. I don't know which I liked more.

This movie was really given a bad rap. I had fairly low expectations going into it and I think it was just as enjoyable as the first one. It has its flaws with story and how it treats Hit Girl's character, but if anything, the first act of the film is much more inspiring than anything in the first movie. What I'm trying to say is: movie good. Fun watch. Good video.
It seriously holds up.
what's all the hubbub

A very funny script that is clearly the work of the hilarious showrunner behind one of my favorite comedies on television (Elizabeth Meriwether, of New Girl.) The film is a lot better than I think most people expect it to be, and although it was probably hurt by being released in close proximity to the very similar Friends With Benefits, I would say it's not a bad movie by any stretch. Jake Johnson, Greta Gerwig, Ludacris,and Mindy Kaling kill it in secondary roles, too. Kevin Kline is weirdly unrecognizable to me in it.

Equal parts hilarious and emotional, a wonderful performance from Mike Birbiglia that is similar in tone to his incredible 2012 film "Sleepwalk With Me." Calling this a stand-up set isn't really fair- as comedic as it is, it's also a truly honest and touching series of stories about relationships and love that happens to be rather funny. Can't recommend enough.
Very good film, but I'm having trouble deciphering the greater, supposedly-pretentious meaning that fueled so many teens and young adults to become filmmakers in the early 2000s.
The climax of this film is an incredibly uneven escalation.
Rian Johnson is a flawless man.
This should have been a much, much bigger film this year. I absolutely cannot wait to watch this again.
Much much better than I expected it to be, actually.
I have never seen anything that fits the definition of "spectacle" more.

movietitle: A Good Day to Die Hard
review: Somehow this manages to be the most aesthetically exciting Die Hard film, but also the most annoying Die Hard film visually. There are some incredible scenes, including the stylish opening credit sequences and the climactic McClane saves the day scene at the end, but in between it is shots with annoying visual grain and overwrought "grittiness" for the sake of nothing. As for the action & plot itself, after marathoning all five of them in one day, it's tied for the‚Ä¶

movietitle: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift
review: Bad.

I feel guilty giving this film 9 stars because a level that high is usually reserved for the high brow films that leave both you and the Academy voters starry-eyed and feeling smart, but fuck that. I really really enjoyed this film. Incredible cast, wonderful storyline, a really fun heist thriller that actually managed to surprised me. I'm excited to see it again.
Beautiful, exciting, well-acted. The Gosling-Stone romance is unnecessary and undeveloped, but Josh Brolin, Giovanni Ribisi, and Sean Penn are terrific.
Eh.
why did i watch this again. why did i watch this a second time, of sound body and mind
this is like the 10th time i've seen this film, and it makes me laugh every single time.
very funny, but also very stupid
stupid sexy tatum
One of my favorites. I can't believe there are people that hate this film. It's near-perfect.
Hilarious.
Even better the second time around.
THIS IS 40 is funny, and the supporting cast is terrific, but it's WAY too long, has a lot of unnecessary scenes, and a lackluster plot.

It hits all the romantic comedy clich√©s, but it gets a pass for actually being funny while doing so. Alison Brie's English accent is the first in recent memory to not be awful, as many American-English accents are. Chris Pratt is definitely the comedic standout, and it's a shame the wedding scene is so sweet and creative because it means it can't be done in real life now without being fairly unoriginal. Gooooood movie.
A brilliant retelling of Homer's Odyssey with the stunning cinematography and terrific performances the Coen Brothers have become known for since.

movietitle: Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy
review: Turns out ANCHORMAN is still a funny movie when I'm not 13 years old. Somehow the least funny parts of it are what became quotable, though.

A brilliant film with a brilliant cast. My only complaint is how misleading Gary Oldman's advertised involvement is. (He's in the film for maybe 10 minutes total.) Though the bloody moments are few and far between, they're gruesome, and they only strengthen an already terrific film.
Brutal and seemingly unintentionally pulpy, but surprisingly good action flick. Don't expect Citizen Kane.

I think it suffers from pacing/editing issues that could be attributed to Tarantino's first film without his longtime editor Sally Menke, but that only slightly detracts from the film. A terrific, brutal, hard, tense, at times hard-to-watch, and thrilling entry into Tarantino's trademark filmography of bad-ass flicks.

My biggest issue with the film is that it seemed way out of its era. Premium Rush felt like a movie I'd see on Nickelodeon in 2002 with a young, recently-formerly-teenage heartthrob in the prime role, i.e. Clockstoppers, or Agent Cody Banks or something. The acting wasn't very good either. There was a really weird, unnecessary cameo by Sleigh Bells in a single scene.
STILL GOLD. Best movie of the year potential.
Dumb. Occasionally funny moments. But dumb.

Whoa. Dramatic, emotional, terse, and sad. A terrific movie that reaches a stunning climax that makes me both root for Denzel and curse him as loud as I possibly can. Kelly Reilly and Denzel Washington both deserve Oscar nominations at the very least for their roles.
One of the best films of the year. Tense, thrilling, dramatic, and glorious. If you miss this movie, you're fucking up.
I watched this movie on my tenth birthday. It was my favorite movie for a solid month or so. I tried rewatching it recently and unsurprisingly my glasses were not so rosy. Very bad movie.

A fantastic, hilarious, gripping film. You can see part of the ending (or I guess the middle since it's revealed closer to the 1-hour mark) coming a mile away, but it's still terrific. Believe it or not, this movie might even be the biggest mindfuck of the year.
Better than I remember... but I remember it being really, REALLY bad so I guess that doesn't mean much. Not a bad action movie, but not a good movie overall either.

Absolutely one of the best classics. It's strange to describe a film taking place almost entirely in one room as thrilling, but 12 Angry Men was. As was it gripping and terrifically acted. I'm rarely so engrossed in classic, all-dialogue, black and white films, but 12 Angry Men is an exception, and an exceptional one.
The pacing is very very off in this film, but it's still a pretty good movie.
I really need to stop watching movies at 3 in the morning just because they're on TV. They are rarely good.
Soul skaters rule.
Wow. WOW. Possibly the best film of the year. Bruce Willis, JGL, and Emily Blunt are all fantastic, and the story is gripping, emotional, tense, and beautiful. Definitely a modern sci-fi classic.

One of the best Pixar films made. If you haven't seen WALL-E lately, watch it again. It's beautiful, emotional, mesmerizing, and fantastic, and it's some terrifically twisted irony that anyone could make me feel more for a robot than I do for most humans.

Psychotic, insane, SUPER tense, twisted, upsetting, and fully deserving of its NC-17 rating. And I liked it.That said, I am NEVER eating a fried chicken leg again. Stunning performances by McConnaughey, Hirsch, and Gerson.

A lot funnier than I thought it'd be, and definitely less stupid than the first film, even if it's still fairly stupid. I'd never call it a "comedy masterpiece" and I'd never hold it up as an example for anything spectacular, but its self-awareness and absurd comedy is terrific for a late night dose of light chuckling.

Save for the unnecessary romantic subplot, constant "remember the TV show? wink wink" moments, and most of the breaking out montage in the middle of the second act, I still maintain that The A-Team is a terrific and fun action film, and one that was largely underrated in its original run in theatres.

The very example of a divisive film. Everybody either loves this movie or hates it, and I fall in the former camp. It's possibly the most beautiful film I've ever seen, and if you can't see it in a theatre, you should seek it out on Blu-Ray on a large-ass television. It's a wonderful picture of a 50s family that might be slow at times, but it really gives you a terrific feel for all of the characters, despite not having a "story" per-se. Sean Penn is pointless in it.

This is probably one of the most stressful films I have ever watched. It's awful, and despite it being under 90 minutes, it just felt so long. I wouldn't recommend this to anybody under pretty much any circumstance.

movietitle: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
review: THE ASSASSINATION OF JESSE JAMES BY THE COWARD ROBERT FORD is wonderful. Beautifully shot, terrific acting all around, great tale. That said, it is far too long.

One of Wes Anderson's best. A perfect ensemble cast, a terrific blend of drama and comedy, with neither being too heavy. Probably the film that would serve best as an example of Anderson's style as an auteur.

Very funny. Great introduction to the Coen Bros. for anyone unfamiliar with their filmography, as it's chock-full of their trademarks. A great argument to anybody that says Nicolas Cage isn't a good actor.

Easily Sandler's best. Stunning cinematography, wonderful story, a great tale of loneliness and love. I'm still a bit confused about a bit of the film (particularly the harmonium's role and the crash at the beginning of the film) but great. There's also an interesting Superman fan theory about the movie that is interesting and worth a read.

Great film. Cliche, shit plot, but terrific acting from everyone involved, and a lot of funny moments. Easily Seann William Scott's best film and acting, although it's not like he had much competition with American Pie being the film he's most known for.
